title: How to correctly order sequences of tenses in English - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer begs the question, “Who’s asking?” If you are talking about the usual order in which tenses and aspects are taught and presented in English language class books, then you would find something like this:  This order is not only illogical in terms of usefulness, but it also has absolutely no bearing on what is easiest or most frequent. This order has been used historically to teach languages. It is a construct created by early philologists who believed that ‘simple’ was simple, (which it isn’t), and decided to teach it first. If you are asking because you want to teach English, I suggest that you throw this in the trash and listen to and read authentic English. Make your own chart based on the frequency of the tenses and aspects you hear being used by real people. Think about the function as well as the tense-aspect. For example, consider the present continuous as it is presented in most class books. You have a page filled with images of people doing various activities. The activity is that the students take turns asking, “What is she doing?” while the other answers, “She is reading.” or “They are listening to music.” Now, how often do real people talk about right now? If you asked me, “What are you doing?”, as my husband often does when I have a vacuum in my hand, I would reply, quite sarcastically and not very happily, “What the f^&%k does it look like I’m doing?” So, asking annoying questions isn’t really something I want to teach my students. Do we use the present continuous? Yes, but far more frequently for other functions than ‘right now’. Think carefully about the language you are teaching and be very wary of traditional charts.

It’s not realy clear what you’re asking about with this question. Obviously, the commenter so far have different interpretations. Is the the sequence in which tenses are learned or taught? Is it the sequence of time, like past, present, future? Or, are you asking about how tenses are used to establish a sequence of actions in complex sentences? The answer to any of these questions is pretty complex. If you leave a comment that clarifies what your asking, I would be happy to give you an answer.
